channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Climate activists — rethink fossil-fuel subsidy cuts

Marine heatwaves: definition duel heats up

item.title: Audit AI search tools now, before they skew research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01613-w

Generative AI could be a boon for literature search, but only if independent groups scrutinize its biases and limitations.
item.dc:title: Audit AI search tools now, before they skew research
item.dc:creator: Michael Gusenbauer

item.title: Three climate policies that the G7 must adopt — for itself and the wider world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01586-w

By taking the lead in innovative climate action, the seven richest economies can create a virtuous circle to help the world decarbonize faster.
item.dc:title: Three climate policies that the G7 must adopt — for itself and the wider world
item.dc:creator: Edward B. Barbier

item.title: An extreme La Niña is linked to Australia’s mega-fires
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01588-8

Tiny atmospheric particles from gargantuan wildfires that began in late 2019 helped to trigger La Niña conditions in 2020.
item.dc:title: An extreme La Niña is linked to Australia’s mega-fires

item.title: I was deathly afraid of the sea — now I work to protect it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01617-6

Conservationist Loyiso Dunga aims to guard kelp, a crucial resource in South African waters that is home to invertebrates, fish and mammals.
item.dc:title: I was deathly afraid of the sea — now I work to protect it
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Prejudice in technology, and the necessity of time: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01624-7

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Prejudice in technology, and the necessity of time: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: How one man's rare Alzheimer’s mutation delayed the onset of disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01610-z

Genetic resilience found in a person predisposed to early-onset dementia could potentially lead to new treatments.
item.dc:title: How one man's rare Alzheimer’s mutation delayed the onset of disease
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How geoscientists are making their field more welcoming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01615-8

Grassroots initiatives aim to make the discipline more inclusive of researchers from under-represented communities.
item.dc:title: How geoscientists are making their field more welcoming
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: How oil companies’ soaring profits compare with green-energy investments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01599-5

Fossil-fuel firms report vast earnings as spending needed to curb climate change lags behind.
item.dc:title: How oil companies’ soaring profits compare with green-energy investments
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: How I managed my intense burnout
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01625-6

Work felt unmanageable, and I was always angry and constantly tired. Here’s how I stepped back, says Kelly Korreck.
item.dc:title: How I managed my intense burnout
item.dc:creator: Kelly Korreck

item.title: Brain-based treatment for menopausal hot flushes approved by FDA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01628-3

Investigations into the impact of menopause on the brain have yielded a new way to treat troublesome symptoms without hormones.
item.dc:title: Brain-based treatment for menopausal hot flushes approved by FDA
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Brain imaging: fMRI advances make scans sharper and faster
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01616-7

Researchers are finding ways to improve one of neuroscientists’ favourite tools: functional magnetic resonance imaging.
item.dc:title: Brain imaging: fMRI advances make scans sharper and faster
item.dc:creator: Diana Kwon

item.title: Nature's Take: Can Registered Reports help tackle publication bias?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01609-6

Nature staff take on the big topics that matter in science.
item.dc:title: Nature's Take: Can Registered Reports help tackle publication bias?
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Mary Elizabeth Sutherland
Federico Levi

item.title: Prized dinosaur fossil will finally be returned to Brazil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01603-y

Following theft accusations, a German museum is set to hand over a one-of-a-kind dinosaur specimen with feather-like structures.
item.dc:title: Prized dinosaur fossil will finally be returned to Brazil
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: Science on a shoestring: the researchers paid $15 a month
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01397-z

Scientists based in resource-poor regions describe how they tackle salary uncertainty, power outages and equipment shortages.
item.dc:title: Science on a shoestring: the researchers paid $15 a month
item.dc:creator: Adam Levy

item.title: Counted at last: US federal agency to pilot PhD survey with questions on LGBT+ scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01623-8

The National Science Foundation, which had mostly omitted data collection on sexual orientation and gender identity from its workforce surveys, will launch a model programme this year.
item.dc:title: Counted at last: US federal agency to pilot PhD survey with questions on LGBT+ scientists
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: ‘The disease will be neglected’: scientists react to the WHO ending mpox emergency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01581-1

Researchers worry that certain regions, including Africa, will suffer if global attention moves away from the outbreak.
item.dc:title: ‘The disease will be neglected’: scientists react to the WHO ending mpox emergency
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Daily briefing: Citation padding gets papers accepted
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01626-5

Researchers who are coerced into manipulating their paper’s citations are more likely to get their work published. Plus, hammerhead sharks ‘hold their breath’ during deep dives and lab-grown monkey embryos reach 25 days.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Citation padding gets papers accepted
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Forgotten
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01556-2

A life disconnected.
item.dc:title: Forgotten
item.dc:creator: João Ramalho-Santos

item.title: How light makes nearby particles do the twist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01568-y

Light travelling through a fibre can impart a twist to glass spheres if the light itself is not twisting.
item.dc:title: How light makes nearby particles do the twist

item.title: Non-Abelian braiding of graph vertices in a superconducting processor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05954-4

A unitary protocol for braiding projective non-Abelian Ising anyons in a generalized stabilizer code is implemented on a superconducting processor, allowing for verification of their fusion rules and realization of their exchange statistics.
item.dc:title: Non-Abelian braiding of graph vertices in a superconducting processor

item.title: Daily briefing: First UK children born with DNA from three people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01601-0

Several babies born in the United Kingdom using mitochondrial replacement. Plus, the first human ‘pangenome’ aims to capture the entirety of our genetic variation and some popular soaps seem to attract mosquitoes.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: First UK children born with DNA from three people
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Hammerhead sharks are first fish found to ‘hold their breath’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01569-x

It pays to be an warm hunter in the cold ocean depths, so the animals shut down oxygen intake to conserve heat.
item.dc:title: Hammerhead sharks are first fish found to ‘hold their breath’
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Carbon capture key to Biden’s new power-plant rule: is the tech ready?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01595-9

Regulation aims to reduce facilities’ emissions of climate-altering gases — a goal that could require carbon burial.
item.dc:title: Carbon capture key to Biden’s new power-plant rule: is the tech ready?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Lab-grown monkey embryos reveal in 3D how organs begin
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01544-6

At 25 days old, specimens could be the oldest primate embryos ever grown outside the womb.
item.dc:title: Lab-grown monkey embryos reveal in 3D how organs begin
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Your favourite soap might turn you into a mosquito magnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01542-8

Mosquitoes tend to prefer the scent of Dawn and Dial over the odour of an unwashed person.
item.dc:title: Your favourite soap might turn you into a mosquito magnet

item.title: Guide to potato genome could make for a bigger spud crop
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01538-4

A genetic manual for the nightshade family, which includes the potato, could help breeders choose the best plants.
item.dc:title: Guide to potato genome could make for a bigger spud crop

item.title: ‘Pangenome’ aims to capture the breadth of human diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01579-9

Mapping a more diverse human genome, and the latest from the Nature Briefing.
item.dc:title: ‘Pangenome’ aims to capture the breadth of human diversity
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Claws like a tardigrade’s give swimming microrobots a grip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01541-9

Miniature robots can cling to blood-vessel walls when kitted out with claws inspired by the water bear’s pincers.
item.dc:title: Claws like a tardigrade’s give swimming microrobots a grip

Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06015-6

Reply to: Quantifying the carbon benefits of ending bottom trawling

item.title: Profiling the human intestinal environment under physiological conditions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05989-7

Variations in microbial composition, phage induction, antimicrobial resistance genes and bile acid profiles are identified by using an ingestible device for site-specific sampling along the intestines.
item.dc:title: Profiling the human intestinal environment under physiological conditions
item.dc:creator: Dari Shalon

item.title: Widespread somatic L1 retrotransposition in normal colorectal epithelium
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06046-z

This study illustrates long interspersed nuclear element-1 retrotransposition-induced somatic mosaicism in normal cells and provides insights into the genomic and epigenomic regulation of transposable elements over the human lifetime.
item.dc:title: Widespread somatic L1 retrotransposition in normal colorectal epithelium
item.dc:creator: Chang Hyun Nam

item.title: Peroxisome biogenesis initiated by protein phase separation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06044-1

A study presents evidence to support a model in which liquid–liquid phase separation of components of the transport machinery mediates formation of transient protein transport channels on peroxisomes.
item.dc:title: Peroxisome biogenesis initiated by protein phase separation
item.dc:creator: Rini Ravindran
Isabel O. L. Bacellar
Xavier Castellanos-Girouard
Haytham M. Wahba

Lydia Kisley
Stephen W. Michnick

item.title: Structural basis of catalytic activation in human splicing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06049-w

Cryogenic electron microscopy images of a spliceosome complex undergoing catalytic activation provide mechanistic insight into how the two ATP-dependent RNA helicases involved in this process, PRP2 and Aquarius, work together.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of catalytic activation in human splicing
item.dc:creator: Jana Schmitzová
Constantin Cretu
Christian Dienemann
Henning Urlaub
Vladimir Pena

item.title: Increased mutation and gene conversion within human segmental duplications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05895-y

A study comparing the pattern of single-nucleotide variation between unique and duplicated regions of the human genome shows that mutation rate and interlocus gene conversion are elevated in duplicated regions.
item.dc:title: Increased mutation and gene conversion within human segmental duplications

item.title: X-ray-to-visible light-field detection through pixelated colour conversion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05978-w

Lithographically patterned perovskite nanocrystal arrays were used to determine radiation vectors from X-rays to visible light and the emission colours of the nanoparticles was used to create images of three-dimensional objects and for phase-contrast imaging.
item.dc:title: X-ray-to-visible light-field detection through pixelated colour conversion
item.dc:creator: Luying Yi
Bo Hou
He Zhao
Xiaogang Liu

item.title: Personalized RNA neoantigen vaccines stimulate T cells in pancreatic cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06063-y

A phase I clinical trial of an adjuvant personalized mRNA neoantigen vaccine, autogene cevumeran, in patients with pancreatic ductal carcinoma demonstrates that the vaccine can induce T cell activity that may correlate with delayed recurrence of disease.
item.dc:title: Personalized RNA neoantigen vaccines stimulate T cells in pancreatic cancer
item.dc:creator: Luis A. Rojas
Zachary Sethna
Kevin C. Soares
Cristina Olcese

item.title: EDA2R–NIK signalling promotes muscle atrophy linked to cancer cachexia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06047-y

Gene expression analysis in muscle tissues showed upregulation of ectodysplasin A2 receptor in tumour-bearing mice and patients with cachectic cancer, and thus therapeutic targeting of relevant pathways may be beneficial in prevention of muscle loss.
item.dc:title: EDA2R–NIK signalling promotes muscle atrophy linked to cancer cachexia
item.dc:creator: Sevval Nur Bilgic
Aylin Domaniku
Batu Toledo
Samet Agca
Bahar Z. C. Weber
Dilsad H. Arabaci
Zeynep Ozornek
Pascale Lause
Jean-Paul Thissen
Audrey Loumaye
Serkan Kir

item.title: High-throughput printing of combinatorial materials from aerosols
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05898-9

The authors report a high-throughput combinatorial printing method capable of fabricating materials with compositional gradients at microscale spatial resolution, demonstrating a variety of high-throughput printing strategies and applications in combinatorial doping, functional grading and chemical reaction.
item.dc:title: High-throughput printing of combinatorial materials from aerosols
item.dc:creator: Minxiang Zeng
Yipu Du
Qiang Jiang
Nicholas Kempf
Chen Wei
Miles V. Bimrose
A. N. M. Tanvir
Hengrui Xu
Jiahao Chen
Dylan J. Kirsch

Brian C. Wyatt
Tatsunori Hayashi
Mortaza Saeidi-Javash
Hirotaka Sakaue
Babak Anasori
Lihua Jin
Michael D. McMurtrey
Yanliang Zhang

item.title: Pan-cancer whole-genome comparison of primary and metastatic solid tumours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06054-z

The genomic differences between primary and metastatic tumours are assessed across 23 cancer types using pan-cancer whole-genome analysis.
item.dc:title: Pan-cancer whole-genome comparison of primary and metastatic solid tumours
item.dc:creator: Francisco Martínez-Jiménez
Ali Movasati
Sascha Remy Brunner
Luan Nguyen
Peter Priestley
Edwin Cuppen
Arne Van Hoeck

item.title: Recombination between heterologous human acrocentric chromosomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05976-y

Comparisons within the human pangenome establish that homologous regions on short arms of heterologous human acrocentric chromosomes actively recombine, leading to the high rate of Robertsonian translocation breakpoints in these regions.
item.dc:title: Recombination between heterologous human acrocentric chromosomes
item.dc:creator: Andrea Guarracino

item.title: De novo evolution of macroscopic multicellularity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06052-1

After 600 rounds of selection, anaerobic snowflake yeast evolved to be macroscopic, becoming around 20,000 times larger (approximately mm scale) and about 10,000-fold more biophysically tough, while retaining a clonal multicellular life cycle.
item.dc:title: De novo evolution of macroscopic multicellularity
item.dc:creator: G. Ozan Bozdag
Seyed Alireza Zamani-Dahaj
Thomas C. Day
Penelope C. Kahn
Anthony J. Burnetti
Dung T. Lac
Kai Tong
Peter L. Conlin
Aishwarya H. Balwani
Eva L. Dyer
Peter J. Yunker
William C. Ratcliff

item.title: A draft human pangenome reference
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05896-x

An initial draft of the human pangenome is presented and made publicly available by the Human Pangenome Reference Consortium; the draft contains 94 de novo haplotype assemblies from 47 ancestrally diverse individuals.
item.dc:title: A draft human pangenome reference

item.title: Mitotic clustering of pulverized chromosomes from micronuclei
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05974-0

The CIP2A–TOPBP1 complex tethers fragmented chromosomes from micronuclei for asymmetric mitotic inheritance, explaining distinct patterns of chromosome rearrangements in cancers and genomic disorders.
item.dc:title: Mitotic clustering of pulverized chromosomes from micronuclei
item.dc:creator: Yu-Fen Lin
Qing Hu
Alice Mazzagatti
Jose Espejo Valle-Inclán
Elizabeth G. Maurais
Rashmi Dahiya
Alison Guyer
Jacob T. Sanders
Justin L. Engel
Giaochau Nguyen
Daniel Bronder
Samuel F. Bakhoum
Isidro Cortés-Ciriano
Peter Ly

item.title: Indian Ocean salinity build-up primes deglacial ocean circulation recovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05866-3

Salinity reconstructions show that Indian Ocean surface salinity increased during glacial periods and that the release of this water via the Agulhas Leakage during deglaciation can trigger abrupt changes in the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation.
item.dc:title: Indian Ocean salinity build-up primes deglacial ocean circulation recovery
item.dc:creator: Sophie Nuber
James W. B. Rae
Xu Zhang
Morten B. Andersen
Matthew D. Dumont
Huw T. Mithan
Yuchen Sun
Bas de Boer
Ian R. Hall
Stephen Barker

item.title: In situ architecture of the ER–mitochondria encounter structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06050-3

Integrative structural biology combining quantitative live imaging, cryo-correlative microscopy, subtomogram averaging and molecular modelling enables in situ determination of the structure of the endoplasmic reticulum–mitochondria encounter complex in yeast.
item.dc:title: In situ architecture of the ER–mitochondria encounter structure
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Wozny
Andrea Di Luca
Dustin R. Morado
Andrea Picco
Rasha Khaddaj
Pablo Campomanes
Lazar Ivanović
Patrick C. Hoffmann
Elizabeth A. Miller
Stefano Vanni
Wanda Kukulski

item.title: Compact [C ii] emitters around a C iv absorption complex at redshift 5.7
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05901-3

Investigation of the physical conditions of the circumgalactic medium led to detection of two compact [C ii]-emitting galaxies with narrow linewidths at a redshift of 5.7, associated with a complex, high-ionization C iv absorption system.
item.dc:title: Compact [C ii] emitters around a C iv absorption complex at redshift 5.7
item.dc:creator: Daichi Kashino
Simon J. Lilly
Robert A. Simcoe
Rongmon Bordoloi
Ruari Mackenzie
Jorryt Matthee
Anna-Christina Eilers

item.title: Loophole-free Bell inequality violation with superconducting circuits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05885-0

A loophole-free violation of Bell’s inequality with superconducting circuits shows that non-locality is a viable new resource in quantum information technology realized with superconducting circuits, promising many potential applications.
item.dc:title: Loophole-free Bell inequality violation with superconducting circuits
item.dc:creator: Simon Storz
Josua Schär
Anatoly Kulikov
Paul Magnard
Philipp Kurpiers
Janis Lütolf
Theo Walter
Adrian Copetudo
Kevin Reuer
Abdulkadir Akin

Nicolas Sangouard
Baptiste Royer
Alexandre Blais
Andreas Wallraff

item.title: A pan-grass transcriptome reveals patterns of cellular divergence in crops
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06053-0

Complementary single-cell and single-nucleus transcriptomic analyses of Zea mays, Sorghum bicolor and Setaria viridis root cells provide insights into the evolution of cell types and gene modules that control key traits in these important crop species.
item.dc:title: A pan-grass transcriptome reveals patterns of cellular divergence in crops
item.dc:creator: Bruno Guillotin
Ramin Rahni
Michael Passalacqua
Mohammed Ateequr Mohammed
Xiaosa Xu
Sunil Kenchanmane Raju
Carlos Ortiz Ramírez
David Jackson
Simon C. Groen
Jesse Gillis
Kenneth D. Birnbaum

item.title: Daily briefing: The unmistakable signature of a coveted quantum phenomenon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01596-8

An interlocked ring pattern of virtual exotic particles has been created in a quantum computer. Plus, an ambitious field trial to vaccinate wild koalas against chlamydia and what record ocean temperatures will mean for wildlife and weather.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The unmistakable signature of a coveted quantum phenomenon
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Superconducting qubits cover new distances
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01488-x

Superconducting quantum bits, a promising platform for future quantum computers, have been entangled over a separation of 30 metres, with a performance that enabled the demonstration of a milestone in quantum physics.
item.dc:title: Superconducting qubits cover new distances
item.dc:creator: Marissa Giustina

item.title: Human pangenome supports analysis of complex genomic regions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01490-3

A pangenome is a collection of DNA sequences that reveals genetic variation between individuals. Four scientists discuss the generation of a human pangenome, and what insights can be gained from it.
item.dc:title: Human pangenome supports analysis of complex genomic regions
item.dc:creator: Arya Massarat
Melissa Gymrek
Brian McStay
Hákon Jónsson

item.title: A clue to the catalytic activation of splicing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01528-6

The processing of messenger RNA during splicing requires the activity of a complex of RNAs and proteins termed the spliceosome. Structural data shed light on previously mysterious aspects of splicing in humans.
item.dc:title: A clue to the catalytic activation of splicing
item.dc:creator: Soo-Chen Cheng

item.title: Erst Island
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01554-4

Out of reach.
item.dc:title: Erst Island
item.dc:creator: Graham Robert Scott

item.title: The ocean is hotter than ever: what happens next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01573-1

Record temperature combined with an anticipated El Niño could devastate marine life and increase the chances of extreme weather.
item.dc:title: The ocean is hotter than ever: what happens next?
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: How my training helps me to address health disparities in multiple myeloma
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01587-9

Irene Ghobrial’s research on early detection of this type of bone-marrow cancer aims to improve patient outcomes, especially among African Americans.
item.dc:title: How my training helps me to address health disparities in multiple myeloma
item.dc:creator: Frances Gatta

item.title: FDA advisers unanimously back over-the-counter birth control pill
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01580-2

Panellists say that making the contraceptive available in the United States without a prescription will benefit women’s health.
item.dc:title: FDA advisers unanimously back over-the-counter birth control pill
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: First UK children born using three-person IVF: what scientists want to know
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01585-x

British fertility regulator reveals that at least one child has been born using mitochondrial replacement therapy, but details are scant.
item.dc:title: First UK children born using three-person IVF: what scientists want to know
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Humans and algorithms work together — so study them together
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01521-z

Adaptive algorithms have been linked to terrorist attacks and beneficial social movements. Governing them requires new science on collective human–algorithm behaviour.
item.dc:title: Humans and algorithms work together — so study them together
item.dc:creator: J. Nathan Matias

item.title: Vaccine boosts T cells that target pancreatic tumours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01526-8

Efforts to tackle pancreatic cancer by harnessing immune cells have had limited success. A clinical trial reports promising results from testing a personalized approach to boosting immune responses to such tumours.
item.dc:title: Vaccine boosts T cells that target pancreatic tumours
item.dc:creator: Amanda L. Huff
Neeha Zaidi

item.title: Detectors that encode angles of incoming light as colour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01366-6

Most light-field sensors — devices that detect the angles of incoming light rays to reconstruct 3D scenes — can detect light only in the ultraviolet and visible wavelength ranges. A newly developed light-field sensor comprising perovskite nanocrystals encodes the angles of incoming visible-light beams and X-rays as different colours.
item.dc:title: Detectors that encode angles of incoming light as colour

item.title: Salty seas sway global glacial cycles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01489-w

Analysis of microfossils in marine sediments spanning the past 1.2 million years suggests that increased intrusion of highly saline waters from the Indian Ocean into the South Atlantic propelled Earth’s deglaciations during this period.
item.dc:title: Salty seas sway global glacial cycles
item.dc:creator: Kaustubh Thirumalai

item.title: First human ‘pangenome’ aims to catalogue genetic diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01576-y

Researchers release draft results from an ongoing effort to capture the entirety of human genetic variation.
item.dc:title: First human ‘pangenome’ aims to catalogue genetic diversity
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Human embryo science: can the world’s regulators keep pace?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01550-8

Concerned by the speed of research, policymakers are looking for alternative ways to establish rules on genome editing and other technologies.
item.dc:title: Human embryo science: can the world’s regulators keep pace?
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Molecular basis for muscle loss that causes cachexia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01527-7

Muscle loss during chronic disease is a life-threatening condition for which there is no effective treatment. The identification of an underlying molecular mechanism might offer new therapeutic targets.
item.dc:title: Molecular basis for muscle loss that causes cachexia
item.dc:creator: Laura Antonio-Herrera
Andreas Bergthaler

item.title: ‘The best way to get it right is to listen to us’ — autistic people argue for a stronger voice in research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01549-1

Despite broader acceptance of neurodiversity, autistic advocates and scientists are still fighting for a chance to set clinical and scientific priorities.
item.dc:title: ‘The best way to get it right is to listen to us’ — autistic people argue for a stronger voice in research
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

item.title: Gut microbes ‘eat’ nanoparticles — leading to microbiome changes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01540-w

Humans can accidentally ingest nanomaterials in consumer products, with unknown effects.
item.dc:title: Gut microbes ‘eat’ nanoparticles — leading to microbiome changes

item.title: Carbon’s social cost can’t be retrofitted to water
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01564-2

Carbon’s social cost can’t be retrofitted to water
item.dc:title: Carbon’s social cost can’t be retrofitted to water
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wheeler
Claudia Ringler
Dustin Garrick
